column4: Title
column18: Observations

column4: *The impact of moisture and temperature on the laminated rhombic hyperbolic paraboloid*
column5: A. Chaubey, A. Kumar, M. Grzegorczyk-Frańczak, M. Szafraniec
column12: Custom FORTRAN FE code (C<sup>0</sup> 9-node shell element)
column14: Free shear (zero transverse shear on top/bottom surfaces)
column15: temperature; moisture concentration; skew angle; ply orientation
column18: Increasing skew angle *decreases* deflection, while higher moisture and hygrothermal loads *increase* deflection.

column4: *Hygrothermal Analysis of Laminated Composite Skew Conoids*
column5: A. Chaubey, A. Kumar, S. Fic, D. Barnat-Hunek, B. Sadowska-Buraczewska
column12: Custom FORTRAN FE code (C<sup>0</sup> 9-node shell element)
column14: Zero transverse shear at surfaces (all sides)
column15: hygrothermal; finite element; shell; laminated composite
column18: Studied effect of skew angle, curvature and ply orientation on hygro-elastic response (higher moisture/load leads to larger deflection).

column4: *Free Vibration Analysis of a Spinning Composite Laminated Truncated Conical Shell under Hygrothermal Environment*
column5: X. Li, X. Zhang, Z. Zhou
column12: Love's thin-shell theory + Hamilton’s principle, solved via Galerkin
column14: Simply supported at small and large edges (S<sub>s</sub>-S<sub>l</sub>)
column18: Temperature, moisture and rotational speed significantly influence natural frequencies; Coriolis force causes mode coupling. Thermal expansion effects are non-negligible.

column4: *Nonlinear free vibration analysis of laminated composite shells in hygrothermal environments*
column8: Laminated cylindrical, spherical, and hyperbolic paraboloid shells (shallow)
column12: Quadratic 8-node isoparametric FE with Green–Lagrange nonlinearity
column17: Shown that increased moisture concentration and temperature reduce stiffness and natural frequencies of laminated shells (nonlinear effects studied for various curvature ratios).
column18: No

column4: *Neural network-based prediction of temperature and moisture influence on vibration of skew laminated composite sandwich plates*
column5: V.B. Kallannavar, S. Kattimani, M.E. Soudagar, M.A. Mujtaba, S. Alshahrani, M. Imran
column8: Skew laminated composite sandwich plate (GPL-reinforced faces, viscoelastic core)
column12: FSDT-based FEM (graphite/epoxy faces, viscoelastic core); Levenberg–Marquardt ANN
column15: skew angle; ANN; FSDT; sandwich plate; hygrothermal
column18: Frequencies decrease with higher temperature and moisture content (ANN predicted trends agree with FEM); skew angle and aspect ratio also significantly affect response.

column4: *Experimental and numerical studies on free vibration of laminated composite shallow shells in hygrothermal environment*
column5: M. Biswal, S.K. Sahu, A.V. Asha
column18: Increasing moisture and temperature reduce the free-vibration frequencies; hygrothermal loading leads to lower natural frequencies and possible dynamic instability.

column4: *Effects of moisture on the frequencies of vibration of woven-fiber composite doubly curved panels with strip delaminations*
column5: H. Panda, S.K. Mall, I. Chopra
column18: Natural frequencies decrease noticeably with increased moisture content; high moisture or delamination significantly reduce vibration frequencies.

column4: *Effect of temperature and moisture on free vibration of skew laminated hybrid composite and sandwich plates*
column8: Skew laminated hybrid composite & sandwich plates
column18: (Inferred) Frequency decreases with rising moisture and temperature (hygrothermal softening effect).

column4: *Free vibration analysis of a skew sandwich plate with bamboo biocomposite and PLA core under temperature and moisture conditions*
column15: skew sandwich; bamboo composite; moisture; vibration
column18: (Likely) Frequency decreases with increased moisture/temperature in the composite sandwich.

column4: *Free Vibration of Skew Fiber-reinforced Composite and Sandwich Panels*
column5: S. Basavanth Kallannavar, A. Ravindra, S. Kattimani
column8: Skew fiber-reinforced composite and sandwich panels
column18: (Likely) Moisture absorption lowers natural frequencies.

column4: *Vibration behavior of thermally stressed composite skew plates*
column18: (Likely) Elevated temperature/moisture reduce stiffness and frequencies.

column4: *Stochastic free vibration of multilayered helicoidal composite shells under thermal conditions*

column5: V.B. Kallannavar, M.E. Soudagar, R.V. Puranik

column5: X. Zhang, Y. Zhou, K. Sobhy
column8: Laminated conical shell with elastic foundation
column18: (Experimentally) frequencies decrease with moisture and foundation stiffness affects response.
